name: Peer
description: A peer can connect to other peers and listen for connections.

children.name: id
children.description: Other peers can connect to this peer using the provided ID. If no ID is given, one will be generated by the brokering server. The ID must start and end with an alphanumeric character (lower or upper case character or a digit). In the middle of the ID spaces, dashes (-) and underscores (_) are allowed.It's not recommended that you use this ID to identify peers, as it's meant to be used for brokering connections only. You're recommended to set the metadata option to send other identifying information.

children.name: key
children.description: API key for the cloud PeerServer. This is not used for servers other than 0.peerjs.com.PeerServer cloud runs on port 443. Please ensure it is not blocked or consider running your own PeerServer instead.

children.name: host
children.description: Server host. Defaults to 0.peerjs.com. Also accepts '/' to signify relative hostname.

children.name: port
children.description: Server port. Defaults to 443.

children.name: pingInterval
children.description: Ping interval in ms. Defaults to 5000.

children.name: path
children.description: The path where your self-hosted PeerServer is running. Defaults to '/'.

children.name: secure
children.description: true if you're using SSL.Note that our cloud-hosted server and assets may not support SSL.

children.name: config
children.description: Configuration hash passed to RTCPeerConnection. This hash contains any custom ICE/TURN server configuration. Defaults to { 'iceServers': [{ 'urls': 'stun:stun.l.google.com:19302' }], 'sdpSemantics': 'unified-plan' }

children.name: debug
children.description: Prints log messages depending on the debug level passed in. Defaults to 0.
Prints no logs.
Prints only errors.
Prints errors and warnings.
Prints all logs.

name: peer.connect
description: Connects to the remote peer specified by id and returns a data connection. Be sure to listen on the error event in case the connection fails.

children.name: id
children.description: The brokering ID of the remote peer (their peer.id).

children.name: label
children.description: A unique label by which you want to identify this data connection. If left unspecified, a label will be generated at random. Can be accessed with dataConnection.label.

children.name: metadata
children.description: Metadata associated with the connection, passed in by whoever initiated the connection. Can be accessed with dataConnection.metadata. Can be any serializable type.

children.name: serialization
children.description: Can be binary (default), binary-utf8, json, or none. Can be accessed with dataConnection.serialization.binary-utf8 will take a performance hit because of the way UTF8 strings are packed into binary format.

children.name: reliable
children.description: Whether the underlying data channels should be reliable (e.g. for large file transfers) or not (e.g. for gaming or streaming). Defaults to false.Setting reliable to true will use a shim for incompatible browsers (Chrome 30 and below only) and thus may not offer full performance.

name: peer.call
description: Calls the remote peer specified by id and returns a media connection. Be sure to listen on the error event in case the connection fails.

children.name: id
children.description: The brokering ID of the remote peer (their peer.id).

children.name: stream
children.description: The caller's media stream

children.name: metadata
children.description: Metadata associated with the connection, passed in by whoever initiated the connection. Can be accessed with dataConnection.metadata. Can be any serializable type.

children.name: sdpTransform
children.description: Function which runs before create offer to modify sdp offer message.

children.name: 'open'
children.description: Emitted when a connection to the PeerServer is established. You may use the peer before this is emitted, but messages to the server will be queued. id is the brokering ID of the peer (which was either provided in the constructor or assigned by the server).You should not wait for this event before connecting to other peers if connection speed is important.

children.name: 'connection'
children.description: Emitted when a new data connection is established from a remote peer.

children.name: 'call'
children.description: Emitted when a remote peer attempts to call you. The emitted mediaConnection is not yet active; you must first answer the call (mediaConnection.answer([stream]);). Then, you can listen for the stream event.

children.name: 'close'
children.description: Emitted when the peer is destroyed and can no longer accept or create any new connections. At this time, the peer's connections will all be closed. To be extra certain that peers clean up correctly, we recommend calling peer.destroy() on a peer when it is no longer needed.

children.name: 'disconnected'
children.description: Emitted when the peer is disconnected from the signalling server, either manually or because the connection to the signalling server was lost. When a peer is disconnected, its existing connections will stay alive, but the peer cannot accept or create any new connections. You can reconnect to the server by calling peer.reconnect().

children.name: 'error'
children.description:
Errors on the peer are almost always fatal and will destroy the peer. Errors from the underlying socket and PeerConnections are forwarded here.

These come in the following err.type flavors:

children.name: 'browser-incompatible'
children.description: The client's browser does not support some or all WebRTC features that you are trying to use.

children.name: 'disconnected'
children.description: You've already disconnected this peer from the server and can no longer make any new connections on it.

children.name: 'invalid-id'
children.description: The ID passed into the Peer constructor contains illegal characters.

children.name: 'invalid-key'
children.description: The API key passed into the Peer constructor contains illegal characters or is not in the system (cloud server only).

children.name: 'network'
children.description: Lost or cannot establish a connection to the signalling server.

children.name: 'peer-unavailable'
children.description: The peer you're trying to connect to does not exist.

children.name: 'ssl-unavailable'
children.description: PeerJS is being used securely, but the cloud server does not support SSL. Use a custom PeerServer.

children.name: 'server-error'
children.description: Unable to reach the server.

children.name: 'socket-error'
children.description: An error from the underlying socket.

children.name: 'socket-closed'
children.description: The underlying socket closed unexpectedly.

children.name: 'unavailable-id'
children.description: The ID passed into the Peer constructor is already taken.This error is not fatal if your peer has open peer-to-peer connections. This can happen if you attempt to reconnect a peer that has been disconnected from the server, but its old ID has now been taken.

children.name: 'webrtc'
children.description: Native WebRTC errors.

name: peer.disconnect
description: Close the connection to the server, leaving all existing data and media connections intact. peer.disconnected will be set to true and the disconnected event will fire.This cannot be undone; the respective peer object will no longer be able to create or receive any connections and its ID will be forfeited on the (cloud) server.

name: peer.reconnect
description: Attempt to reconnect to the server with the peer's old ID. Only disconnected peers can be reconnected. Destroyed peers cannot be reconnected. If the connection fails (as an example, if the peer's old ID is now taken), the peer's existing connections will not close, but any associated errors events will fire.

name: peer.destroy
description: Close the connection to the server and terminate all existing connections. peer.destroyed will be set to true.This cannot be undone; the respective peer object will no longer be able to create or receive any connections, its ID will be forfeited on the (cloud) server, and all of its data and media connections will be closed.

name: peer.id
description: The brokering ID of this peer. If no ID was specified in the constructor, this will be undefined until the open event is emitted.

name: peer.connections
description: A hash of all connections associated with this peer, keyed by the remote peer's ID.We recommend keeping track of connections yourself rather than relying on this hash.

name: peer.disconnected
description: false if there is an active connection to the PeerServer.

name: peer.destroyed
description: true if this peer and all of its connections can no longer be used.

name: DataConnection
description: Wraps WebRTC's DataChannel. To get one, use peer.connect or listen for the connect event.

children.name: .send
children.description: data is serialized by BinaryPack by default and sent to the remote peer.

children.name: data
children.description: You can send any type of data, including objects, strings, and blobs.

children.name: .close
children.description: Closes the data connection gracefully, cleaning up underlying DataChannels and PeerConnections.

children.name: .on
children.description: Set listeners for data connection events.

children.name: 'data'
children.description: Emitted when data is received from the remote peer.

children.name: 'open'
children.description: Emitted when the connection is established and ready-to-use.

children.name: 'close'
children.description: Emitted when either you or the remote peer closes the data connection.Firefox does not yet support this event.

children.name: .dataChannel
children.description: A reference to the RTCDataChannel object associated with the connection.

children.name: .label
children.description: The optional label passed in or assigned by PeerJS when the connection was initiated.

children.name: .metadata
children.description: Any type of metadata associated with the connection, passed in by whoever initiated the connection.

children.name: .open
children.description: This is true if the connection is open and ready for read/write.

children.name: .peerConnection
children.description: A reference to the RTCPeerConnection object associated with the connection.

children.name: .peer
children.description: The ID of the peer on the other end of this connection.

children.name: .reliable
children.description: Whether the underlying data channels are reliable; defined when the connection was initiated.

children.name: .serialization
children.description: The serialization format of the data sent over the connection. Can be binary (default), binary-utf8, json, or none.

children.name: .type
children.description: For data connections, this is always 'data'.

children.name: .bufferSize
children.description: The number of messages queued to be sent once the browser buffer is no longer full.

name: MediaConnection
description: Wraps WebRTC's media streams. To get one, use peer.call or listen for the call event.

children.name: .answer
children.description: When recieving a call event on a peer, you can call .answer on the media connection provided by the callback to accept the call and optionally send your own media stream.

children.name: stream
children.description: A WebRTC media stream from getUserMedia.

children.name: sdpTransform
children.description: Function which runs before create answer to modify sdp answer message.

children.name: .close
children.description: Closes the media connection.

children.name: .on
children.description: Set listeners for media connection events.

children.name: 'stream'
children.description: Emitted when a remote peer adds a stream.

children.name: 'close'
children.description: Emitted when either you or the remote peer closes the media connection. Firefox does not yet support this event.

children.name: .open
children.description: Whether the media connection is active (e.g. your call has been answered). You can check this if you want to set a maximum wait time for a one-sided call.

children.name: .metadata
children.description: Any type of metadata associated with the connection, passed in by whoever initiated the connection.

children.name: .peer
children.description: The ID of the peer on the other end of this connection.

children.name: .type
children.description: For media connections, this is always 'media'.

name: util
description: Provides a variety of helpful utilities.Only the utilities documented here are guaranteed to be present on util. Undocumented utilities can be removed without warning. We don't consider these to be 'breaking changes.'

children.name: .browser
children.snippet: if (util.browser === 'Firefox') { /* OK to peer with Firefox peers. */ }
children.description: The current browser. This property can be useful in determining whether or not two peers can connect. For example, as of now data connections are not yet interoperable between major browsers. util.browser can currently have the values 'Firefox', 'Chrome', 'Unsupported', or 'Supported' (unknown WebRTC-compatible browser).

children.name: .supports
children.snippet: if (util.supports.data) { /* OK to start a data connection. */ }
children.description: A hash of WebRTC features mapped to booleans that correspond to whether the feature is supported by the current browser.Only the properties documented here are guaranteed to be present on util.supports.

children.name: .audioVideo
children.description: True if the current browser supports media streams and PeerConnection.

children.name: .data
children.description: True if the current browser supports DataChannel and PeerConnection.

children.name: .binary
children.description: True if the current browser supports binary DataChannels.

children.name: .reliable
children.description: True if the current browser supports reliable DataChannels.
